entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 120 ft.

entries.name: Hind Leg Dash
entries: You gain an additional 10 ft of movement speed until the end of your turn whenever you use the {@action Dash|XPHB} or {@action Disengage|XPHB} action.

entries.name: Fanged Jaws
entries: If you hit a target with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you can deal piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d4} plus your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Hunter Gatherer
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Nature|XPHB}, {@skill Survival|XPHB} or {@skill Stealth|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Ancestral Blessing
entries: Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can cast the {@spell Guidance|XPHB} spell on yourself as an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
sizeEntry.entry: Small (about 2–4 ft tall) or Medium (about 4–7 ft tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 ft.

entries.name: Outdoor Adept
entries: You can move across {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} made from earth or foliage without expending extra movement.

entries.name: Protected by Nature
entries: You can attempt to {@action Hide|XPHB} even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain/snow, mist, or other natural phenomena.

entries.name: Friend of Fauna
entries: Once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can cast the {@spell Beast Bond|XGE} spell without the material components needed and without expending a spell slot.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
sizeEntry.entry: Small (about 2–4 ft tall) or Medium (about 4–7 ft tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Chilled Anatomy
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Cold damage. You also know the {@spell Ray of Frost|XPHB} cantrip.

entries.name: Compacted Snow
entries: You can move through the space of any creature that is a size larger than you, but you can't stop in the same space. Additionally, you can squeeze through a space that is large enough for a creature one size smaller than you without movement penalties.

entries.name: Frigid Construct
entries: You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep. You can finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in 4 hours if you spend those hours unmoving; during this time you are indistinguishable from a snowman, but retain consciousness. You don't need to eat, drink or breathe.

entries.name: Glacial Form
entries: Once per long rest, you can cast the {@spell False Life|XPHB} spell without using the material components or expending a spell slot, and harden your body into ice.

entries.name: Guiding Light
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can produce dim light in a 20 ft radius from your nose. You can end this effect as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: Antler Defence
entries: Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB} as a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can lower your antlers and enter a defensive stance. Until the start of your next turn, you have a +2 bonus to your {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB} against melee attacks.

entries.name: Hooves
entries: If you hit a target with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you can deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d4} plus your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Born to Navigate
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Perception|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

raceFluff.name: Canisar
entries: Canisars are proud, fox-like humanoids, renowned for their fierce sense of kinship. They are famously described by others as having wits as sharp as their teeth. Their thick fur hides powerful muscles, and each of their fingers ends in a retractable claw. Respect is hard to gain from a canisar, but they will defend their friends with tenacity and devotion.

Canisars are covered in coarse fur that can vary between deep brown, grey, white, orange or black, which often comes with facial stripes or ringed markings. Most canisars live in woodland burrows, hidden beneath thick vegetation, mud or snow. Others roam the surface world, integrating into wider society while maintaining ties to their original burrows. Canisar culture is deeply ancestral, guided by reverence for family and lineage. Each canisar travels with stories and relics of their ancestors, and gives gifts to their friends and family throughout the year during different canisar festivals.

raceFluff.name: Hederan
entries: Hederans are living embodiments of alpine trees, sentient beings of bark and leaf whose bodies host moss, holly and fungi. Their outer skin is made of thick bark that toughens with age, and beneath lies a network of green, sap-filled muscle. Twigs and berries sprout unpredictably, with the brightest clusters gathered around their heads. Their leaves and bark vary in colour, and are as diverse as the lands they live in.

Hederans have extraordinary lifespans, with some reaching over a thousand years of age. Every two centuries or so, a hederan enters a rare blooming phase when the flowers on its body release pollen and a single silver seed forms upon its back. The seed must be planted within a week, or it will wither away, but from it a new hederan sapling will grow.

Once planted by their parent, a hederan forms a deep bond with the soil of its homeland. They serve as guardians of winter forests, and maintain the balance of nature. Solitary by nature, they can live for centuries without meeting another of their kind, and no one knows how many exist across the world.

raceFluff.name: Snowborn
entries: The snowborn are a young species, and have existed for less than fifty years. They first appeared during a notably long and cold winter, which snowborn commonly refer to as 'The First Flurry'. Beyond that, little is known about their creation, though elemental magic was clearly involved. New snowborn have appeared and vanished over the years since their origin, yet the pattern of their life and rebirth remains a mystery even to them. Each fleeting snowborn lives for up to 20 years.

A snowborn's body is formed of compacted snow. They have a small sphere for a head, branch-like limbs, and they can harden into ice to protect themselves. Despite their coal eyes and carrot noses, they perceive the world as keenly as any other species. Snowborn enjoy using clothing as self-expression, like a jaunty hat or colourful scarf.

raceFluff.name: Tarandus
entries: For millennia, the tarandus have been known as a society of explorers devoted to charting and understanding the world. Their culture prizes discovery, and they believe that their lives are best spent travelling, observing and creating maps that guide others along safe paths.

All tarandus possess antlers that rise roughly a foot above their heads. Their dark-red noses can emit a gentle glow, often used for reading maps in dim light or signalling danger to their allies. Tarandus fur ranges from deep brown to pure white, shifting with age, climate or diet. They usually wear simple outfits, though more ornate garments and armour may be loaned to individuals by their herd in honour of taking on a specific role or responsibility.

Their settlements are filled with map-halls and navigation schools, where trained explorers record the land, stars and seas with care. Some tarandus dedicate their lives to perfecting the art of map making, while others roam the world as scouts, guides or couriers, ensuring that their knowledge of routes and geography remains current.

Tarandus herds are large and communal, sharing duties such as child-rearing and foraging. They maintain strong ties between herds through regular gatherings where new maps and discoveries are exchanged. As most tarandus are used to the safety and rhythm of herd life, those who travel alone often join adventuring groups as temporary companions.

item.name: Babble Pipes
entries: Made from pieces of several mismatched instruments, these panpipes have been tied together into a single, discordant whole.

Once a day, this instrument can be played as an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}, releasing a horrid symphony. Each creature in a 30 ft {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} who can hear the music must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition for 1 minute.

A {@condition Frightened|XPHB} creature takes the {@action Dash|XPHB} action and moves away from you by the safest route on each of its turns, unless there is nowhere to move. If the creature ends its turn in a space where it doesn't have line of sight to you, the creature makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a successful save, the spell ends on that creature.

item.name: Boots of Soft Landing
entries: A pair of brown, fur-lined boots that have been finely crafted. The boots are quilted, and have ceramic soles that emit a colourful magical energy.
While wearing these boots, you always land on your feet and cannot be knocked {@condition Prone|XPHB}. Additionally, your fall speed is capped at 60 ft per round, and you take no damage from falling.

item.name: Calling Quills
entries: These antique quills and writing pads were originally owned by siblings. When the family set up four different branches of their toy-making business across the continent, they developed the magical pads as an easy way to communicate orders and stock levels with one another.
When something is written on one of the four parchment pads, it is visible on all the other parchment pads. Messages are visible for 12 hours, at which point the pads magically absorb the ink.

item.name: Gold Rings of Might
entries: These five ornate, golden rings once belonged to an evil monarch. Alone, each is simply an inert piece of dress jewellery. When they are brought together, they hum with dark and ominous energy.

The Gold Rings of Might have 5 charges, and regain 1 expended charge every day at dawn. If you expend the last charge, the item loses its enchantment and does not recharge. If a creature is wearing the Gold Rings of Might, they can innately cast the {@spell Shocking Grasp|XPHB} spell as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action.
The wearer can expend 1 charge to cast {@spell Lightning Bolt|XPHB} (save {@dc 15}) as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, without using the materials or a spell slot.
Alternatively, the wearer can expend 3 charges to cast {@spell Chain Lightning|XPHB} (save {@dc 15}) as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, without using the materials or a spell slot.

item.name: Goose Egg Healing Grenade
entries: Whether this smooth, pearlescent egg was truly laid by a mythical golden goose is the subject of much debate. What is known for sure, however, is that the egg has remarkable healing powers.

Once per day as an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}, this item can be thrown into an unoccupied space up to 40 ft away and release a wave of healing energy. Creatures within a 30 ft radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} from the point the Goose Egg Healing Grenade lands regain {@dice 2d8 + 4} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, or {@dice 5d8 + 4} if they are within a 10 ft radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere}. The item's magic heals up to six creatures at a time, starting with the creatures with the lowest {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.
This item's magic has no effect on undead creatures or constructs.

item.name: Metronome Drum
entries: This neatly painted {@item drum|XPHB} is attached to a leather shoulder harness, so it can be struck at waist height. Local folklore suggests that this instrument can have an almost hypnotic effect on those in earshot, but only if played at the correct tempo.

You can play this {@item drum|XPHB} as an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}. Once a day, up to three Humanoids within a 30 ft {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} of the {@item drum|XPHB} beat must succeed on a {@dc 14} saving throw or have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition and become {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} towards you. The targets make their saving throws with advantage if you or your allies are fighting them. The {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition ends after 1 hour or when you stop playing the {@item drum|XPHB}. When the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition ends, the targets know they were {@condition Charmed|XPHB} by you.

item.name: Phial of Stoutmilk
entries: This thick glass bottle holds viscous, white, fizzing liquid. Tied around the bottle's neck is a worn tag that once listed the ingredients and stated dose.

For 1 hour after drinking this potion, when you take bludgeoning damage, reduce the total damage taken by {@dice 1d4}. Your Strength and Constitution scores both increase by 2 until the potion's effects wear off.

item.name: Swansong Staff
entries: This gnarled, oak {@item staff|XPHB} ends in a crook reminiscent of a swan's neck. It is clearly ancient, and was only recently uncovered from deep within an elven ruin.
You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Once a day, if the wielder is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the Swansong {@item Staff|XPHB} immediately animates (using the stats of an {@creature Animated Broom|XMM}) to protect them. The weapon acts on the wielder's initiative. If the animated weapon is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or if its wielder regains consciousness, it becomes inanimate once more.

item.name: Trident of Henchantment
entries: A jasper effigy of a chicken's head rests at the top of this {@item trident|XPHB}, and an egg-shaped amethyst is fixed to its base. It is a strange weapon, but is highly coveted by farmers and livestock owners.

This magic weapon has 4 charges, and regains {@dice 1d4} expended charges at dawn. When you use the {@action Attack|XPHB} action with this weapon, you can immediately expend 1 of its charges to cast the {@spell Polymorph|XPHB} spell (save {@dc 15}) and transform your target into a hen (AC 10, HP 1, {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} 30 ft) for 1 hour. If you expend the weapon's last charge, roll {@dice 1d4}. On a 1, yolk explodes out of the egg-shaped gem at the base of the {@item trident|XPHB} and the weapon loses its enchantment.

item.name: Turtle Dove Dagger
entries: From the tip of its thick steel blade to the base of its golden handle, each knife shimmers with a buzz of illusory energy.

While wielding a pair of Turtle Dove Daggers, you can create an illusory copy of yourself as an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} twice per long rest. The illusion lasts for 1 minute, or until you take damage. The illusion appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within 30 ft of you. You can take an {@action Attack|XPHB} or {@action Magic|XPHB} action on your turn to attack or cast a spell as if you were in the illusion's space, but you must use your own senses. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can move the illusion up to 30 ft to a space you can see, but it must remain within 120 ft of you. Additionally, when both you and your illusion are within 5 ft of a creature that can see the illusion, you have advantage on attack rolls against that creature.

item.name: Wand of Dancing
entries: Light glistens across this shiny, black wand; the ribbons that flow from its tip twinkle and sparkle in rhythmic patterns.

You can spin and twirl holding this wand to cast the {@spell Otto's Irresistible Dance|XPHB} spell (save {@dc 14}). The wand can be used to cast the spell as many times as you like each day, however, once a creature fails its saving throw against the spell cast by this wand, the wand cannot be used to cast the spell again until dawn the next day.
Partridge feathers and a scarlet hood give this predominantly dull-brown leather armour some brighter detailing. Intricate embossing around the waist tells the story of a lonely bird.

You have a +1 bonus to Armour Class while wearing this armour. Twice per day, when an enemy moves within 5 ft of you, you can fly up to 10 ft away from them in a flurry of feathers as a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} without provoking {@action opportunity attack|XPHB|opportunity attacks}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The drake casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks):

trait.name: Illumination
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, the drake can produce dim light in a 15 ft radius, or bright light in a 15 ft radius and dim light for an additional 15 ft radius. The drake can end this effect as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

trait.name: Prickly Pines
entries: If a creature successfully hits the drake with a melee attack, the creature takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day, or 4/Day in Lair)
entries: If the drake fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drake makes three Rend attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of (A) Incandescent Breath or (B) Spellcasting to cast {@spell Color Spray|XPHB|Colour Spray}.

action.name: Rend
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9}, reach 10 ft. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) Slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Radiant damage.

action.name: Incandescent Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 19}, each creature in a 90 ft long, 5 ft wide {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line}. {@actSaveFail} 55 ({@damage 10d10}) Radiant damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

legendary.name: Bright Tail Lash
entries: {@actSave str} {@dc 17}, a creature the drake can see within 15 ft. {@actSaveFail} 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Radiant damage, and the target is knocked {@condition Prone|XPHB}.

legendary.name: Pounce
entries: The drake moves up to half its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}, and it makes one Rend attack.

legendary.name: Twinkling Lights
entries: The drake uses Spellcasting to cast {@spell Faerie Fire|XPHB}.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: The pudding gremlin explodes when it dies. {@actSave dex} {@dc 11}, each creature in a 5-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the pudding gremlin. {@actSaveFail} 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Fire damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: If the pudding gremlin doesn't move on its turn, it has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} when taking the Hide action.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft, {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) Slashing damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 11}, each creature in a 15 ft {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Fire damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

action.name: Create Gremlin (1/Day)
entries: If the pudding gremlin is within 10 ft of an ordinary pudding, it can turn the ordinary pudding into another pudding gremlin. This new pudding gremlin appears in an unoccupied space within 10 ft of the original pudding gremlin and acts as its ally.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The sphinx casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}):

trait.name: Inscrutable
entries: No magic can observe the sphinx remotely or detect its thoughts without its permission. Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) checks made to ascertain its intentions or sincerity are made with {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sphinx makes two Claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 6}, reach 5 ft, {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) Slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Cold damage.

bonus.name: Freezing Glare {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 13}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail 1} The target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition and repeats the save at the end of its next turn if it is still {@condition Restrained|XPHB}, ending the effect on itself on a success. {@actSaveFail 2} The target has the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition instead of the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition, and is turned into an ice statue.

Guardians of flourishing alpine forests, great fir drakes live peacefully among their saplings. Each day, the iridescent drakes use powerful magic to replenish their forest's soil and promote the growth of their beloved fir trees. Over the centuries, villagers and townsfolk have learned to live in peace with these largely benevolent beings.

People who live near a great fir drake's lair can visit its forest home and leave the drake small shiny tokens under trees they wish to cut down. If the people return the next day to find the tokens have been gathered and taken, they know the great fir drake has given its blessing for those tree to be felled. In thanks, villagers decorate the trees with lights to resemble the drake. Those who fail to leave an offering for the drake's hoard and cut down its fir trees enrage the legendary creature, and should prepare to face its thrashing, needle-covered tail.

The first pudding gremlin was the result of a misguided mage attempting to bring drama to their dinner table. The gremlin leapt from the plate and was soon causing havoc in the kitchen, where it created a small army of currant-filled compatriots. This ability to transform regular puddings into duplicates has resulted in pudding gremlins being a widespread pest during the festive season.

The pudding gremlin's sharp green horns and claws pose an immediate threat to those trying to quash these creatures. However, it is the tiny brandy scented inferno that resides within each pudding gremlin that provides the drama the mage had wished for. Even when defeated, these not-so-sweet treats create an unwelcome surprise, exploding and spraying clumps of sticky, scalding-hot cake over their foes.

Camouflaged against the ice, a solitary snow sphinx is on the prowl. A shock of dark humanoid hair whips around a feline face, revealing piercing blue eyes that can freeze foes with a single glance. Compared to its desert-dwelling cousins, this sphinx is far less likely to be defeated with reason or logic. Although a snow sphinx can speak, it generally greets its prey with claws and teeth rather than riddles or philosophical conversation.

Physically, this fearsome creature is well adapted to harsh habitats, such as ice-covered mountains or arctic plains. It has wide paws to stop it sinking into soft snow and thick fur to ward out the cold. The sphinx's muscular wings carry the same spotted markings as its fur; they are strong enough to withstand the bitter winds that whistle across the tundra.

data.name: All Work, No Play
entries: {@i Level 3–4 Adventure. Mysterious. Rescue. Toy Factory}.

All that {@area Freylie Hipsberry|03e|x} wants for Winterfest is to spend time with her family. However, her parents have been working non-stop in the toy factory and haven't been home in days. Can the party figure out what's keeping Freylie's family so entranced by their work?

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries: {@i "It's the night before Winterfest, and the sun is setting over the snow-dusted roofs of the village. Perusing the notice board, you can see that all the festive events in the run-up to the holiday have been and gone. The only people left on the streets are hurrying home to their families. All except a small dwarven child who reaches up on tiptoes to pin a handwritten note to the bottom of the board."}

Freylie is only 11 years old, but has found herself all alone on Winterfest Eve. It's been nearly a week since her parents last came home from work at the local toy factory, and yesterday her older brother went to fetch them and didn't come back. Earlier today, Freylie got a note saying none of them would be home for Winterfest. She begs the party to visit the factory and reunite her family for the holiday. When the party arrive, they realise the workers are all under the spell of magical drums.

entries.name: Suggested Story
entries: Set the scene, have Freylie approach the party and explain that her family is missing, then continue:

items: Freylie shows the party the note she received, and offers them all her Winterfest gifts if they help her.
Freylie points the party towards the factory, but is too scared to go with them. The streets are eerily quiet as the party approach the factory.

At the factory, the lights are on, chimneys are smoking and crates are stacked up in the yard. Two six-foot-tall {@area toy soldiers|040|x} ({@creature Animated Armor|XMM}) patrol the site, and faint drumming can be heard from inside.
The party must get past the locked gates.
As the party enter the factory yard, the sentries attack them, along with four sharpened wooden candy canes ({@creature Animated Flying Sword|XMM|Animated Flying Swords}).

Inside, the party find the workers are under the spell of four {@item Metronome Drum|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|Metronome Drums}, played by four toy soldier drummers that obey {@area Mr Melville|042|x}.

The party must break the spell, but 10 {@condition Charmed|XPHB} workers ({@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}) will fight to resist them. Mr Meville orders the drummers to try and charm the party using the magical instruments.
When all the drums are silenced, the workers are free from the spell and rush home to be with their families. The Hipsberry family invite the party to join them and Freylie for the holiday.

entries.name: Freylie Hipsberry
entries: {@i Dwarf, Female, 11} ({@creature Commoner|XMM})
Freylie is very worried about her family. She sees the party as her only hope for a happy Winterfest.
{@i "Peeping out from between a heavy woollen hat and scarf are two big brown eyes and a button nose covered in freckles."}

entries.name: Toy Soldier Sentries
entries: {@i Wooden Construct} ({@creature Animated Armor|XMM})
These magical constructs have no emotions and can't talk. They only obey orders to guard the yard.
{@i "The wooden guards have painted-on black boots, scarlet uniforms, perfectly circular rosy-pink cheeks and unblinking blue eyes."}

entries.name: Mr. Drusten Meville
entries: {@i Human-Elf, Male, 57} ({@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM})
The stern new factory manager uses constructs and magical drums to control his workers.
{@i "His waxed hair and moustache are the same drab shade of brown as his suit and tie."}

entries.name: Town Notice Board

entries: {@i "Delicate icicles hang from the top of the wooden board, which has been draped in a garland of green foliage and red berries. The notices are coated in frost."}

As well as posters for Winterfest carol concerts, craft sessions and food markets, there are signs advertising work at the factory. A phrase in the job adverts, 'Work Makes Play Happen', also features in the note from Freylie's mother.

entries.name: Factory Gates

entries: {@i "Through the bars of the towering iron gates, you see an upright figure pacing back and forth, face cast in shadow by the sturdy brick walls of the factory."}

The toy factory is on the northern edge of town. It is surrounded by a 10-foot brick wall and two padlocked iron gates with spikes on the top. Crates are stacked up along the edge of the factory, ready to be picked up. Toy soldier sentries patrol the site.

entries.name: Factory Floor

entries: {@i "Wood shavings fly from the workers' benches as they frenetically carve, paint and polish toys. Drums beat steadily in time with their work."}

There are 10 {@creature Cultist|XMM} workers in the factory, including Freylie's mother, father and brother. Each one is sat at their own work bench. Mr Melville stands on a raised gantry. He only joins the fight when two drums are put out of action.

items: {@area Freylie's|03e|x} mother, Mags, carves wooden toys, and her father, Pietr, specialises in painting them.
In many years of working at the factory, Freylie's parents have never had to work such long shifts.
Freylie's brother Toma is 18. He was looking after her until he went to visit the factory yesterday.
The note Freylie received is in Mags' handwriting, but the formal wording matches Mr Melville's ads.
{@area Mr Meville|042|x} was brought in to boost the factory's output of toys (and profits) before Winterfest.
Freylie wants to stay close to home in case her family return, and to prepare a Winterfest meal.
When Toma went to the factory to speak to his parents, he also fell under the spell of the drums.
If a worker receives damage, they get a chance to resist the charming beat of the {@item Metronome Drum|OneShotWondersHolidayPack}.
The {@area toy soldier drummers|040|x} were only ordered to drum, so won't attack the party unless attacked first.
The {@item Metronome Drum|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|Metronome Drums} were prototype toys, which Mr Meville saw a new purpose for.

entries.name: Quest Rewards
entries: The party can claim any {@item Metronome Drum|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|Metronome Drums} that survive the fight. The workers also gift them each a {@item Figurine of Wondrous Power|XDMG} in thanks. The Hipsberry family invite the party home for a Winterfest meal, and Freylie offers them her gifts.

entries.name: Easier (Level 1–2)
entries: Try removing the flying swords. You could only have two {@area drummers|040|x} and six {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}, including Mr Meville.

entries.name: Harder (Level 5–6)
entries: The sentries could be {@creature Shield Guardian|XMM|Shield Guardians}. Mr Melville could have another {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM} as his assistant, together controlling 12 {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}.

data.name: Blessing of the Drake
entries: {@i Level 5–6 Adventure. Adventurous. Investigation. Wilderness}.

Lanterns hang from the trees, jolly carols ring out, and feasts are being prepared. This could be the best Winterfest yet! But, the Great Fir Drake hasn't come to bless the village this year, and a local druid fears disaster. Can the party find the beast before the festival begins?

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries: {@i "Pine-cone bunting is strung from roof to roof, and fir wreaths hang on every front door and fence post. The people around you are upbeat and preparing for the annual winter celebration of nature and family. Not everyone is joyous in the run-up to Winterfest, however. You were contacted by the settlement's local druid, Gram, who fears something may be wrong with the area's mighty draconic guardian."}

{@area Ysilwen|05d|x}, the {@creature Great Fir Drake|OneShotWondersHolidayPack}, guards a territory spanning fifty miles around the settlement. The people of the village place carved tokens, beaded jewellery and coins beneath a statue in the weeks leading up to Winterfest, as an offering of thanks and peace to the mighty beast. Normally, Ysilwen visits the village to collect the offerings and then isn't seen again until the next year. There has been no sign of the creature this year, and {@area Gram|05b|x} is starting to worry this Winterfest may end in disaster

entries.name: Suggested Story
entries: Set the scene, have Gram offer to pay the party if they can find Ysilwen in her lair, then continue:

items: Gram draws the party a map: head east from the village, cross a bridge, then go north to Pineshelter Cave. Gram gives them a shard of amber resin as an offering, in case the drake is angry with the village.
The party walk to the forest and start their search.
A trail of damage leads over the bridge to a thicket.
While investigating, the party are attacked by a kobold spellcaster ({@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM}) and three {@creature Kobold Warrior|XMM|Kobold Warriors}, who were hiding in the branches.
Pressing on, they discover the drake injured in her lair. She tells them about {@area Lotorrix|05f|x} and his ambush.
Ysilwen asks the party to remove the nets caught in her claws and spears buried in her side. The party need to be careful of her sharp spines.
Ysilwen asks the party to ride her into battle against Lotorrix. They all charge towards the thicket.

The party find Lotorrix, four kobold spellcasters ({@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM|Cultist Fanatics}) and ten {@creature Kobold Warrior|XMM|Kobold Warriors} in the thicket. The mob attacks. Once per round, a party member may use one of Ysilwen's actions instead of their own. The party take half damage while riding the drake.
If Lotorrix is defeated, Ysilwen carries the party to the village and blesses its people for Winterfest.

entries.name: Gram Iceback
entries: {@i Orc-Human, Female, 48} ({@creature Druid|XMM})
A local druid who looks after the offering ceremony every year. She is growing more and more stressed.
{@i "Gram wears thick goatskin wraps and fur boots. She stares into the forest, biting her nails."}

entries.name: Ysilwen, the Great Fir Drake
entries: {@i Dragon, Female, 677} ({@creature Great Fir Drake|OneShotWondersHolidayPack})
This drake has guarded her territory for centuries. She was injured by Lotorrix and his rabble, then fled.
{@i "Her green scales twinkle, and her tail ends in a glowing star. She pants heavily. Bruises and red scratches on her side are causing her pain."}

entries.name: Lotorrix the Bitter
entries: {@i Dragon, Male, 91} ({@creature Young White Dragon|XMM})
A spiteful dragon who leads a rabble of kobolds. He wants to take the pine forest territory for himself.
{@i "The cackling dragon's oversized snout is full of crooked teeth. His jaw sits to the left slightly, as if it was dislodged in a brutal fight long ago."}

entries.name: Drake Statue

entries: {@i "A stone likeness of the Great Fir Drake gazes into the quiet pine forest. At its base rests a broad bowl brimming with coins, beaded jewellery and wood-carved tokens."}
This is where the villagers, led by Gram, give offerings to the drake every year as a sign of gratitude. Gram is sat on a rickety stool beneath the statue, next to the stone bowl full of offerings.

entries.name: Bloody Thicket

entries: {@i "This was clearly the site of a desperate and hard-fought battle. Broken trees lie shattered on the floor, and splashes of red streak across the white snow."}

Lotorrix and his rabble ambushed Ysilwen here. There are signs of two large creatures fighting, bent weapons, and four slain kobolds. Ysilwen used an illusion spell to confuse Lotorrix and the kobolds before fleeing back to her lair, injured.

entries.name: Pineshelter Cave

entries: {@i "The lair of the drake is lined with dazzling green crystals. Offerings from past Winterfests sit in organised piles around the cave, like treasured gifts."}

Pineshelter Cave is marked on the map, but the entrance is hidden by an illusion of a snowdrift. Ysilwen is curled up in her lair, licking her wounds. She may be temporarily hostile if the party don't announce themselves.

items: There are fewer Winterfest offerings this year; {@area Gram|05b|x} thinks that's why the drake is absent.
Gram once stumbled across {@area Ysilwen's|05d|x} lair when she was gathering potion ingredients.
The kobolds used to inhabit a network of mountain caves, until {@area Lotorrix|05f|x} arrived and claimed it.
The kobolds are terrified of Lotorrix and his icy wrath, and will do anything he orders them to do.
Lotorrix wants to extend his territory into the pine forest, and sees Ysilwen as a threat.
Lotorrix and his rabble fanned out to search for Ysilwen after she fled the ambush, to no avail.

entries.name: Quest Rewards
entries: Gram will pay 300gp if the party can find the {@creature Great Fir Drake|OneShotWondersHolidayPack}, and she will gladly gift her {@item Staff of the Python|XDMG} if they bring the drake to bless the village. Each kobold wears a white agate on a necklace (10gp each) to show their allegiance to Lotorrix.

entries.name: Easier (Level 3–4)
entries: You could remove the {@creature Cultist Fanatic|XMM|Cultist Fanatics} from the adventure, and make Lotorrix a {@creature White Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}.

entries.name: Harder (Level 7–8)
entries: The party could take full damage while riding the {@creature Great Fir Drake|OneShotWondersHolidayPack}. Lotorrix could bring his {@creature White Dragon Wyrmling|XMM} younger sibling to the fight, too.

data.name: Catching a Chill
entries: {@i Level 11–12 Adventure. Spooky. Confrontation. Castle}.

A supernatural storm of ice abruptly halts all Winterfest preparations. No hearth will burn, no candle will light. High above the town, wails echo from the spiteful ghosts of Sifter Castle. The townsfolk turn to the party for help, can they bring warmth back and save Winterfest?

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries: {@i "You wake up from the cold. The holly-trimmed windows of the small bedroom you rented last night are frosted, and your breath mists in the morning air. You can hear pounding hail and raised voices outside, and you know something is wrong. After you finish dressing, but before you can get downstairs, the floorboards creak outside your room and there are three timid knocks at your door."}

Every Winterfest, haunting screams drift down from Sifter Castle, a slate-grey stronghold that clings to a cliff above the town. The townsfolk have become used to this grim tradition, but this year something's changed. A terrible blizzard blew down from the castle, and no fires will catch in town this morning. The town's people are freezing and quickly falling ill. The local healer {@area Morrig|097|x} is overrun. Known to be adventurers, the party are hired to end the curse of Sifter Castle once and for all; they must save Winterfest before it's too late.

entries.name: Suggested Story
entries: Set the scene, have {@area Nilia|095|x} ask the party to come downstairs as quickly as they can, then continue:

items: Nilia and Morrig explain the curse of Sifter Castle and beg the party to drive out {@area Raimond|099|x} for good.
Nilia presents books detailing Sifter Castle's layout and the history of the Sifter family. When the party are ready, they can journey up to the castle.
Inside the castle, the party find the Sifter family (five {@creature Mummy|XMM|Mummies}) eating a ghostly banquet without Raimond. When disturbed, they turn and attack.

The party must destroy four spell circles to break the curse. On entering a new room, roll {@dice 1d4} and have the party find: 1. {@dice 2d6} angry castle staff ({@creature Specter|XMM|Spectres}); 2. skeletal remains of the previous residents; 3. {@dice 1d4} vengeful castle guards ({@creature Wraith|XMM|Wraiths}); 4. floors and surfaces coated in slippery ice.
Spell circles are in the first, fourth and fifth rooms the party explore. A final spell circle is in the crypt.

As the party open and investigate the crypt, Raimond screams and darkness falls. The chamber is enveloped by a {@spell Hunger of Hadar|XPHB} spell. Raimond attacks, vowing to imprison the party forever.
If Raimond is defeated, the party can return to Nilia and receive her thanks and promised reward.
Warmth will return to the town, and the party will be invited to join in the evening festivities.

entries.name: Nilia Syncla
entries: {@i Bugbear, Female, 52} ({@creature Commoner|XMM})
Runs the beloved Red Reindeer Inn. She bakes tasty mince pies, and has a keen interest in local history.
{@i "Nilia's grey fur is plaited with bells on strings, and a wooden spoon juts from her overalls."}

entries.name: Morrig Fraysur
entries: {@i Human, Male, 48} ({@creature Commoner|XMM})
Healer who works in the infirmary. He rushed to the inn to ask if Nilia could spare any beds or supplies.
{@i "Layered scarves, mittens and a baggy knitted jumper keep Morrig warm. His round cheeks and runny nose are red and chapped from the cold."}

entries.name: Raimond Sifter, the Sleepwalker
entries: {@i Elf, Male, 759} ({@creature Mummy Lord|XMM})
Lord of Sifter Castle. His hatred of Winterfest bound him, his family and his staff to the castle in death.
{@i "An elderly elf whose expression is contorted into a bitter scowl. His nightgown is dirty and torn, and his bony fingers end in black nails."}

entries.name: Red Reindeer Inn

entries: {@i "A huge holly wreath wrapped up in a red bow is hung on the stone chimney breast next to the counter. But there's no fire in the cold and empty hearth."}

The upper floor holds five neat, well-kept bedrooms. The lower floor has a reception desk, a few tables and a small kitchen opposite the welcoming oak door. Outside, it's quiet, as everyone is at home trying to stay warm.

entries.name: Castle Grounds

entries: {@i "Wind and wails blow through the old, decrepit ramparts of Sifter Castle. Its dark iron gates warped and twisted after a rockslide years ago, and now block your passage to the slumping ruin."}

The trek up the crumbling cliff path to the castle is steep and slippery. In and around the castle, the supernatural weight of the curse presses down on the party ' they must regularly test their constitution or gain exhaustion.

entries.name: Castle Crypt

entries: {@i "Raimond's howling reaches an unbearable pitch as you journey into the musty basement of the castle. Your boots kick up dust; no living thing has ventured down here in years."}

The door to the crypt is magically sealed until all the other spell circles have been destroyed. Raimond sealed himself inside the crypt to escape the town's songs and bell-ringing years ago. He absolutely hates Winterfest.

items: The town guards aren't experienced in magic; they believe it is too dangerous for them to clear Sifter Castle.
{@area Nilia|095|x} has bookshelves full of historical tomes on the town, its surrounding area, and its residents.
Nilia inherited her love of records from her mother, who was the town's scribe before she retired.
{@area Morrig|097|x} fears that the frost-bitten townsfolk in the infirmary will not survive the relentless blizzard.
{@area Raimond|099|x} lived in Sifter Castle with his wife Petan, and their children Osgar, Berrel, Piole and Clem.
In life, Raimond Sifter was a necromancer. He specialised in communicating with undead spirits.
The village's loud Winterfest celebrations would interrupt Raimond's ghostly rituals every year.
Raimond found his family's wish to celebrate Winterfest a nuisance and forbade it.
When Raimond's family celebrated anyway, he cursed them all and locked himself in the crypt.
After years of research in the crypt, Raimond found a way to amplify the curse by using spell circles.

entries.name: Quest Rewards
entries: Nilia will offer the party a slapdash reward of 140gp from the inn's till, four pieces of handmade jewellery (100gp each), and free room and board for the holidays. The party can find 420gp and three fine oil paintings (750gp each) in Raimond's crypt vault.

entries.name: Harder (Level 13–14)
entries: The castle doors could be trapped with {@spell Glyph of Warding|XPHB|Glyphs of Warding}; the {@creature Specter|XMM|Spectres} could be {@creature Wight|XMM|Wights}.

entries.name: Even Harder (Level 15–16)
entries: Raimond's malice could make him a {@creature Balor|XMM}. Try swapping the {@dice 2d6} {@creature Specter|XMM|Spectres} for {@dice 2d4} {@creature Ghost|XMM|Ghosts}. The castle crypt could be enveloped by a {@spell Circle of Death|XPHB} spell.

data.name: Gift Getaway
entries: {@i Level 7–8 Adventure. Thrilling. Acquisition. Snowy Mountain}.

The party were invited to be guests at the village's Winterfest jamboree this year, it's a time of gift giving and joy. But, on the morning of Winterfest, disaster strikes. The village's gifts have been stolen! Can the party steal back the gifts before they're damaged or lost forever?

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries: {@i "It's the crisp morning of Winterfest, and there are already people gathering in the village square. You expected carol singing and laughter, but you're met with raised voices and weeping. As you move further into the heart of the village, you notice its elderly leader, Lord Gregorus, standing in the middle of a restless crowd. He wipes his foggy glasses, then reads from a scrappy note as the crowd hushes."}

What should be a time of celebration and gratitude has turned into confusion, as the village's gifts have all been stolen. The bandit gang responsible flew into the village on the back of their {@creature Snow Sphinx|OneShotWondersHolidayPack} leader, bagged the gifts, then disappeared. The bandits left a ransom note: they want 1000gp in exchange for the gifts, or else the gifts will be destroyed. They will throw a handful of gifts off the White Falls waterfall every 30 minutes from 8 a.m. until payment is received in full. {@area Gregorus|078|x} refuses to pay.

entries.name: Suggested Story
entries: Set the scene, have Gregorus read the ransom note aloud and the clock strike 8 a.m., then continue:

items: Gregorus pleads with the party to stop the bandits and get the gifts back. He loans them his sleigh, pulled by four {@creature Elk|XMM}, and marks White Falls on their map. The party set off down the snowy mountain.
The old sleigh's runners snap shortly after they depart. Failed attempts to fix them will cost the party 30 minutes.
A raging hailstorm (like the {@spell Ice Storm|XPHB} spell) rolls in. The party must decide whether to press on and take damage, or take cover and lose 30 minutes.
The party cross a frozen lake, which breaks as they drive. If they fall overboard as the sleigh lurches, they take cold damage and lose 30 minutes.
At White Falls, {@area Sorrel|07a|x} and four {@creature Berserker|XMM|Berserkers} taunt the party. If confronted, the gang become hostile.
After two rounds of combat, {@area Ossymar|07c|x} angrily flies into the battle and attacks the party member with the highest hit points. She criticises Sorrel loudly.
Ossymar won't fight to the death. She will bargain with the party once they have the upper hand.
Victorious, the party can load the remaining gifts into their sleigh and ride safely back to the village.
They are thanked by Gregorus, and can take part in the village's all-day Winterfest jamboree.

entries.name: Lord Gregorus Rynch
entries: {@i Gnome, Male, 498} ({@creature Commoner|XMM})
An old and wise noble who the villagers see as a leader. He talks slowly, and commands attention.
{@i "Wool and silk swaddles Gregorus' tiny frame. His trembling hands hold a note. He brings it close to his face and squints to examine it."}

entries.name: Sorrel Heddalir
entries: {@i Elf, Female, 40} ({@creature Gladiator|XMM})
Sorrel leads a bandit gang of four {@creature Berserker|XMM|Berserkers}. She was promised easy money if she worked for Ossymar.
{@i "The gang leader wears a thick coat made from the hide and fur of an arctic fox. She leans on her chipped spear and spits when she sees you."}

entries.name: Ossymar, the Pale Claw
entries: {@i Sphinx, Female, 191} ({@creature Snow Sphinx|OneShotWondersHolidayPack})
This conniving sphinx wants to decorate her cave lair with riches. She uses Sorrel and her thugs as pawns.
{@i "The sphinx is the size of a draft horse. She has snow leopard spots across her body and wings."}

footnotes: ↑ Use Maximum Hit Points and Damage Rolls for this creature.

entries.name: Village Square

entries: {@i "The settlement sits on top of a mountain, and from the village square you can see for miles. Stalls selling cocoa and mulled wine have been set up, making the whole area smell delightful."}
Villagers are gathered around Gregorus, who stands on a raised dais next to a clocktower and well. The decorated fir tree is damaged, and the piles of wrapped gifts at its base are now all gone.

entries.name: Snowy Mountain

entries: {@i "The snow starts to get heavier, and it looks like a storm might be brewing. The steep ride down the mountain is going to be a slalom of pine trees and ice."}
In the freezing winter, the journey down the mountain is treacherous. The mountain is covered in powder snow and ice, and there are multiple hidden frozen lakes.
There are outcrops that can be used as temporary shelters from the hail.

entries.name: White Falls

entries: {@i "Stepped rock leads down to a cliff edge. Five tents and a campfire sit nearby, a shelter for the thieves. On the other side of the cliff, a rushing glacial waterfall cascades hundreds of feet into the canyon below."}
The bandit gang stole all 24 gifts from the village. Every 30 minutes, they throw {@dice 1d4} gifts over the edge.

items: It is village tradition to leave gifts in the square under the decorated fir tree on Winterfest Eve.
The gifts are sentimental trinkets like family heirlooms, handmade pottery and carved tokens.
{@area Sorrel|07a|x} grew up in the village, so knows that its people pile gifts under the fir tree before Winterfest.
{@area Ossymar|07c|x} convinced Sorrel to steal from her own community by giving her a magical shield.
Some villagers tried to stop the bandits, but succumbed to Ossymar's charms and magic.
Sorrel's bandit gang would have preferred to stay independent, and don't trust Ossymar.

entries.name: Quest Rewards
entries: {@area Lord Gregorus|078|x} promises the party 200gp if they stop the bandits, and 30gp for every undamaged gift the party brings back. Sorrel is using a platinum {@item +2 Shield|XDMG|Shield +2} that Ossymar gave her, which can be taken from Sorrel if she falls in battle.

entries.name: Easier (Level 5–6)
entries: Sorrel could use {@creature Tough Boss|XMM} stats and have four {@creature Tough|XMM} gang members. Ossymar could arrive only once the gang is defeated.

entries.name: Harder (Level 9–10)
entries: Sorrel could be a {@creature Mage|XMM} taught by Ossymar. Try the {@spell Otiluke's Freezing Sphere||Freezing Sphere} spell for the blizzard.

data.name: Just Desserts
entries: {@i Level 1–2 Adventure. Light-Hearted. Defence. Banquet Hall}.

Winterfest is all about enjoying good food with good company, and the town's annual banquet is the biggest feast of all. All the party need to do to get an invite is to complete some simple set-up jobs. How hard can it be to put out plates for a few puddings?

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries: {@i "Stepping into the venue, you're hit by a wall of warmth and a medley of mouthwatering scents. The blend of spices, freshly baked pastry and roasting meats is the unmistakable smell of Winterfest. As you shake off your heavy layers and stamp the snow from your boots, other staff hurry past you clutching supplies. It seems there's still a lot to do to have everything ready for the banquet tonight."}

The party have been hired to help with preparations for the town's Winterfest banquet. The event gives the town's most influential figures a chance to get together and feast on seasonal treats ' including the famous Winterfest dessert table. The party were told that if they complete the day's tasks well, they'll be able to attend the feast and sample the puddings. Unfortunately, one eager staff member has tried a little too hard to make this Winterfest feast a magical night to remember.

entries.name: Suggested Story
entries: Set the scene, have {@area Artum|021|x} greet the party and show them into the banquet hall to start work, then continue:

items: Artum gives the party a list of decorating tasks. He also tells them that there are a lot of prestigious guests coming this evening, then goes to check on other preparations.
Task 1: The party must hang fir garlands. The ceilings are high and the ladders are rickety; the risk of falling or dropping something is high.

Task 2: The party must go to the scullery to collect the table settings. The room is a mess, and it is a challenge to find matching sets of china. Wheeling the crockery back to the banquet hall requires strength and dexterity to avoid breaking anything.

Task 3: Just as the party are about to finish laying the table, Artum rushes in. A {@creature Mastiff|XMM} startled two carriage horses, both of which are now loose and trampling decorations outside. The party must help {@area Bolla|023|x} calm the scared, kicking {@creature Draft Horse|XMM|Draft Horses}.
The first six guests arrive and enter the banquet.

Suddenly, two {@creature Pudding Gremlin|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|Pudding Gremlins} leap from the dessert table and start duplicating. The party must stop the gremlins trashing the banquet hall, while protecting the terrified guests from harm.
When the Pudding Gremlins are defeated, the chef admits he tried a new, experimental pudding recipe. The banquet continues in peace.

entries.name: Artum Gresit-Hughes
entries: {@i Tiefling, Male, 48} ({@creature Commoner|XMM})
The event organiser is run off his feet, supervising staff in the banquet hall, kitchen and stables.
{@i "The lilac-skinned tiefling has a long green quill tucked behind one ear. He's wearing a black apron over a navy velvet evening jacket."}

entries.name: Bolla Ritinswort
entries: {@i Gnome, Female, 174} ({@creature Scout|XMM})
A carriage driver hired to bring guests to the event. She's well-meaning, but easily distracted.
{@i "The driver's fur-lined overcoat swamps her small frame, and a rigid cap falls over her face."}

entries.name: Elias Joster
entries: {@i Elf, Male, 32} ({@creature Commoner|XMM})
Hired at the last minute to cater the banquet, Elias wants to show off his potential to wealthy guests.
{@i "The chef is covered from top to toe in splashes of sauce, pudding batter and scorch marks. Loose currants are nestled in his flour-streaked hair."}

entries.name: Banquet Hall

entries: {@i "You stand at the top of a grand, double-sided staircase looking out at the opulent room. The central table is bare, as are the walls."}

The banquet hall has a raised seating area at one end, where the dessert table has been set up. Artum tells the party where the garlands should be hung: along the balconies, up the stairs and criss-crossing the ceiling.

entries.name: Scullery

entries: {@i "The shelves are groaning with the weight of mismatched plates, bowls, serving platters, candlesticks, loose silverware, glass decanters and more."}

The scullery is a small storage room. The route there involves narrow corridors and two flights of stairs. Inside the scullery, several different sets of tableware are all muddled up. The party must find the Winterfest set, which has a mistletoe design.

entries.name: Driveway

entries: {@i "Dust is swirling around the driveway. The skittish horses have kicked up the gravel path that had been so neatly raked when you first arrived."}

Bolla has driven her carriage, pulled by two horses, right up to the door. She was meant to go to pick someone up first, but forgot. When the horses get loose, they knock over the lanterns that have been placed along the driveway.

items: The guests at this charitable banquet include business owners, nobles and local politicians.
{@area Artum|021|x} has hosted the event in a local ballroom for 10 years, and it has always run perfectly.
A rival event poached Artum's usual staff, so he's had to recruit last-minute replacements.
{@area Elias|025|x} found a 'show-stopping' pudding recipe in an old book, but didn't realise it was a spell book.
The dog that startles the horses belongs to Elias. It is called Toffee, and is just trying to play.
The loose horses are called Jingle and Jangle, but {@area Bolla|023|x} can never remember which is which.

entries.name: Quest Rewards
entries: Artum has agreed to pay each party member 25gp each for a day's work, plus a seat at the banquet if they do a good job. Any wealthy guests the party protect in combat will give them a 5gp tip and Elias gives them a tin of spiced biscuits to take away.

entries.name: Harder (Level 3–4)
entries: A {@creature Dire Wolf|XMM} could attack the horses and the party. Try four {@creature Pudding Gremlin|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|Pudding Gremlins} interrupting the feast.

entries.name: Even Harder (Level 5–6)
entries: Two {@creature Winter Wolf|XMM|Winter Wolves} could attack the horses. Eight {@creature Pudding Gremlin|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|Pudding Gremlins} could trash the hall, including starting fires that spread if they're not put out.

book.name: One Shot Wonders: Holiday Adventure Pack
book.author: Roll & Play Press

data.name: Introduction
entries: Prepare for a festive adventure! Face off against flame-breathing puddings, present-stealing bandits, and joy-sucking spirits. Encounter arctic monsters like the Snow Sphinx and Great Fir Drake. Give your players new seasonal character species to play as, then delight them by dropping a magic item or two underneath the tree.
This collection contains:

items: 5 brand-new festive one-shots
4 seasonal species
3 wintry monsters
12 magic items
5 festive battle maps
Token pack
Quick-start campaign setting

entries: All these festive adventures are set around the fantasy holiday of Winterfest, and they're also easy to adapt for an existing winter holiday in your home game.

entries.name: What is Winterfest?
entries: When the seasons shift and the cold nights draw in, the citizens of Mirabilis start to look forward to Winterfest. The beloved annual celebration honours warmth, light and togetherness, in a time that could otherwise feel dark and isolating.

Evergreen garlands are strung from the ceiling and sweet treats are given an extra touch of warming spice. Families and friends gather to feast and sing merry tunes around the fire. Every community has their own set of traditions and folktales to share with passing adventurers.
So, at this special time of year, when magic swirls with the snowflakes in the air, why not tell a festive tale of your own? You and your party will be feeling the warmth of Winterfest in no time.

entries.name: What is Mirabilis?
entries: If you want to play your one-shot in the quick-start campaign setting of Mirabilis, head to the {@book Continuing the Adventure|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|2} chapter for more lore about the magical realm.

entries.name: One-Shot Wonders
entries: The one-shots and battle maps in this collection are based on the adventure design of {@i One-Shot Wonders} and {@i The Map Library}, the multi-award-winning book and map compendium by Roll & Play Press.

{@i One-Shot Wonders} is full of ready-to-run adventures designed for easy prep and maximum impact. Each session plan breaks down the key characters, locations and plot points you need to run a great game. The easy-to-follow structure helps keep game masters on track, and the extra details make improvising a breeze.
Whether you run weekly games, host an RPG club, or want to try GMing for the first time, {@i One-Shot Wonders} has you covered. Grab your dice and get ready for an unforgettable adventure!

entries.name: Getting Ready to Play
entries: Ready to get started? Here's a quick checklist to make sure you're ready for your next game:

items: Flick through these 5 adventures to pick your next session. Keywords at the beginning of each adventure tell you the level, theme, objective and location of each adventure.
Read through the session plan to discover the key characters, locations and plot details. Think about how you'll handle major moments in the adventure, and practise your NPC voices!
Familiarise yourself with the game rules and stats of the creatures who appear in the session.
Gather the things you'll need to support you, like a GM screen, maps, miniatures, dice, stationery and snacks.
You could give each of your players a pre-generated character, or guide them to create their own.
Keep the {@i One-Shot Wonders} session plan open, so you can refer back to it throughout the game.
Keep an eye on the time, so you can pace your adventure and take breaks when needed.
Enjoy your one-shot adventure!

entries.name: Adventure Structure
entries: Each one-shot adventure in this collection is broken down into the same core elements:

entries.name: Introduction
entries: Every one-shot session plan begins with three keywords, which provide information about the adventure's theme, objective and setting. There is also a brief summary of the plot to give you a taste of what's to come.

entries.name: Level
entries: Each adventure is balanced for a party of four adventurers within the session's level range. There are also suggestions on how to adjust encounters for parties of different levels in the {@b Level Changes} section of each adventure and in the {@book Adventuring Levels|OneShotWondersHolidayPack|0|Adventuring Levels} section below.

entries.name: Starting the Adventure

entries: "Our story begins with a simple turn of the page..."

This section helps you set up the adventure, including how and why the party enter the action. Text in boxes can be read aloud to help set the scene, but the additional plot context is for the game master (or GM) only.

entries.name: Suggested Story
entries: A list of bullet points gives you a chronological summary of the adventure, broken down into scenes.

items: Navigate the key events of the adventure as you play, including important interactions and travel.
This section also highlights when combat is likely. If a story refers to waves of foes, stagger their arrival.

Sometimes, players may make a choice that takes the story somewhere that wasn't planned. If this happens, adapt a story element so you can get back to the action. For example, if the party don't go to an enemy's lair, have the enemy ambush them where they are!

entries.name: Important Characters
entries: Important NPCs are listed with a useful description. The creature stats suggested may be different to their species to help level the encounter.

entries.name: Quick Stats
entries: The Quick Stats table gives an overview of each creature's Armour Class, Hit Points, Initiative modifier and a key ability in combat. All creatures in the one-shots feature in the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} or are included in this sourcebook.

entries.name: Key Locations
entries: Set the scene with a description of the environment, building or room the action is taking place in. You'll also find hints for hazards, traps and other noteworthy details that are present in the area.

items: Extra nuggets of information your players might discover during the story are given in bullet points.
These can be dropped into the adventure at the GMs discretion to help expand on the plot.
You could hide these secrets in diary entries, overheard conversations, visions, dreams, or anything else you can think of!

entries.name: Quest Rewards
entries: Check out this section for ideas on how to reward your party for a job well done. This could include payment made by a quest giver, a trinket given by a grateful NPC, or even a magic item.

entries.name: Adventuring Levels
entries: Whether your party's characters are just setting out, or are experienced heroes, there's a quest for them in this collection. To make sure your chosen session challenges your players, but doesn't overwhelm them, consider a few key factors before you start.

entries.name: Party Size
entries: Each session's difficulty assumes a party of four adventurers. If you have fewer than four, you could use ideas from the EASIER suggestion, or add an NPC ally to assist the group. For larger groups, use the HARDER ideas to increase the challenge.

entries.name: Adjusting Monster Difficulty
entries: Creature stat blocks use averaged out dice rolls when suggesting {@book Hit Points|PHB|9|Hit Points} (HP) and damage dealt. However, adjusting these values to their maximum (↑) or minimum (↓) is another way to tweak the difficulty of an adventure, while keeping the story the same. This technique can also be used to represent a creature that is stronger than average, such as the dominant {@creature Wolf|XMM} in a pack (↑), or weaker than average, such as a young Wolf cub (↓).
For example, an average {@creature Commoner|XMM} has HP 4 ({@dice 1d8}), and their {@item Club|XPHB} attack deals 2 ({@dice 1d4}) bludgeoning damage.

items: {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoner ↑} would have HP 8 ({@dice 1d8}), and their Club attack deals 4 ({@dice 1d4}) bludgeoning damage.
{@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoner ↓} would have HP 1 ({@dice 1d8}), and their Club attack deals 1 ({@dice 1d4}) bludgeoning damage.

data.name: Continuing the Adventure
entries: The tips in this chapter help you turn your one-shot sessions into an epic campaign.

entries.name: The Realm of Mirabilis
entries: The session plans in this collection are designed to fit seamlessly into your homebrew worlds, or pre-established settings, either as one-shot adventures or side quests. However, if you're looking for a bespoke world to set your adventure in, look no further...

entries.name: Welcome to Mirabilis
entries: From the highest peaks of the Thornscale Mountains to the wide expanse of the Kupika Desert, citizens of Mirabilis enjoy general peace and prosperity, but it is not a land completely without threat. The realm is rich with magic, bringing both boons and peril to daily life.

Marvellous creatures soar overhead and lurk in dark caverns. Ancient curses and strange prophecies shape the fabric of reality. Powerful mages conjure incredible constructs and terrifying entities. Beings from other realms stray into the world, bringing miracles and mischief with them. Around every bend is a new wonder to behold.

entries.name: Regions
entries: The citizens of Mirabilis share much, including a common language, but different regions also have their own unique identities.

Villages in the Jabali Tundra are often cut off due to bad weather, giving locals a resilient, independent outlook. Ties to spirits and the divine typically have a strong hold in this region, particularly Himaya, the jovial god of hearth-and-home and his impassive partner, Ramad, the god of death.

Heading south, those living in the shadow of the smouldering Mkali Peaks are naturally vigilant and often live in fortified settlements, built during previous periods of conflict. In contrast, the dangers of travel in the Wychwood Marshes are sometimes less obvious. There are limited main roads through this rugged landscape, so residents rely on their knowledge of the environment to guide them.

Mirabilis's central region is the Mellow Valley, where fertile soil nurtures areas of dense woodland and thriving agricultural communities. While the Valley offers safety and security, more adventurous souls are often drawn to coastal towns, unable to resist the siren's call of exploration and new experiences offered by life at sea.

The southernmost region of Mirabilis is the Kupika Desert. Residents of the settlements in this area are famed for providing warm hospitality for those who have ventured through the unforgiving sand dunes.

entries.name: Government
entries: Mirabilis is led by an elected High Council of nine experts in their respective fields. There is widespread approval for these rulers, especially in the capital city of Laagehoven, the nexus of governmental power. While the current Council is considered firm but fair, history tells of some nefarious High Councillors who tried to use their power for selfish or sinister purposes.

In smaller cities and large towns, it is common to find a mayor presiding over local affairs and enforcing the laws of the land. In the far reaches of Mirabilis, the state's authority is less robust. Discontent is found in pockets throughout the land, but there is no widespread support for rebellion.

entries.name: Beyond Its Borders
entries: Historically, the land's greatest threat came from invading forces on its northwest border. A remote area known as the Grim Expanse still bears the scars of battle, even half a century after a peace treaty brought years of protracted war to an end.

To the east of Mirabilis, a winding coastline borders the Fantasian Ocean. Pirates, strange sea beasts and underwater populations can all cause issues for travellers who traverse these waters, despite the best efforts of the realm's naval forces.

entries.name: Mapping Mirabilis
entries: If you are running your one-shot adventures in the realm of Mirabilis, this map can help you find a suitable setting. This versatile selection of settlements and landmarks can also help you describe journeys between quest locations, or provide hometowns for your characters.
1 hex is equal to around 12 miles, or half a day's travel. Bear this in mind when planning out journeys between encounters.

items: Icepeak - Structures in this hilltop town sit at the feet of the Thornscale Mountains, and are built around the shores of the ever-frozen Lake Kuganda.
Usalama - A network of treehouses and stilted buildings form a bustling settlement in the swamp.
Cornbrook - The culinary highlight of the Mellow Valley. There are many delicacies to be found within this large town's thriving markets and shops.
Laagehoven - Over a quarter of the realm's population live within the walls of this vast city. It is the centre of political power in Mirabilis.
Hisan - A stopping point on many busy roads, this wealthy town has a rich equestrian history.
Swanport - A range of food, people, cultures and goods travel in and out of this small, but lively, coastal city. Smugglers also make use of its shores.
Umida - Known as 'the library of the desert', this grand city is a hub for education and the arts. Its population is the second largest in Mirabilis.
Devreach - Parts of this large town are built underground, to protect residents from the heat.
Buaza - This remote village borders a former battlefield, bringing pride and sorrow to its history.
Meander - A tranquil resting point for those travelling north, offering multiple supply stores.
Cragbarrow - Despite its small size, this mining settlement supplies much of the land's coal.
Bandari - This quiet, seaside village is popular with pilgrims due to its many shrines.
Greystone - Energy from nearby volcanoes powers the creations of generations of tinkerers.
Rylgan - Regularly used by those travelling to and from the desert as a place to change steeds.
Jacaranda - Founded as a meeting point between land-dwelling and underwater populations.
Cerulean - Named for the bright waters of a nearby oasis, which nurtures lush native plant life.
Pearlshore - Built from locally mined quartz, this picturesque spot is popular with tourists.
Wonder's End - This ramshackle site at the edge of the desert is home to hardy souls.

entries.name: Notable Landmarks

items: Mount Fyn - Few have reached the summit of the highest peak in the Thornscale Mountains.
The Ridge - The High Council warn civilians not to venture beyond the Ridge, for their own safety.
Icemoon Vale - The source of the sacred Ebcansu river, a spot associated with great divinity.
Plains of l'smere - Named after a great dragon who lived here before Mirabilis was founded.
Nilse Caverns - The further reaches of this deep, dangerous cave system are still uncharted.
Olanic - The larger of two volcanoes known as the Smouldering Sisters; the other is Jyona.
Emerald Grove - This woodland area is rumoured to have a powerful fey presence.
Lake Glaindrop - The deepest lake in Mirabilis provides fresh fish for nearby townsfolk.
Blight Cove - Many ships have fallen foul of these deadly rocks, despite a nearby lighthouse.
The Agate Isles - These islands provide undisturbed habitats for numerous wild creatures.
Haven Island - Once a monastic base, the impressive buildings are now believed to be empty.
Ruins of Panl'ra - The remains of an ancient kingdom are hidden beneath the sand.

entries: Snow-dusted locations like the Thornscale Mountains, Jabali Tundra, Icepeak, Meander and Icemoon Vale are perfect for the wintry adventures in this collection.

entries.name: Plotting a Campaign
entries: Once your players have discovered the world of Mirabilis, they'll be desperate to come back. So, why not link one-shots together into an ongoing campaign?

entries.name: Connecting Stories
entries: If you're building your own campaign or linking one-shots together to create a story arc, there are a few ways you can get started. Here are some examples:

items.name: Monster Type
items.entry: If your party are expert dragon slayers or specialise in destroying the undead, stringing sessions together with the same monster type builds towards their goals.

items.name: Villain
items.entry: A series of seemingly unrelated tasks could reveal clues about a wider plot or conspiracy, orchestrated by a single villain.

items.name: Theme
items.entry: Linking one-shots by theme, like Spooky or Thrilling, lets you lean into a genre or questing style.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: Stories set in the same settlement or location can flow together easily, as adventurers explore the area organically.

entries.name: Pudding Gremlin
entries: The first pudding gremlin was the result of a misguided mage attempting to bring drama to their dinner table. The gremlin leapt from the plate and was soon causing havoc in the kitchen, where it created a small army of currant-filled compatriots. This ability to transform regular puddings into duplicates has resulted in pudding gremlins being a widespread pest during the festive season.

The pudding gremlin's sharp green horns and claws pose an immediate threat to those trying to quash these creatures. However, it is the tiny brandy scented inferno that resides within each pudding gremlin that provides the drama the mage had wished for. Even when defeated, these not-so-sweet treats create an unwelcome surprise, exploding and spraying clumps of sticky, scalding-hot cake over their foes.

entries.name: Snow Sphinx
entries: Camouflaged against the ice, a solitary snow sphinx is on the prowl. A shock of dark humanoid hair whips around a feline face, revealing piercing blue eyes that can freeze foes with a single glance. Compared to its desert-dwelling cousins, this sphinx is far less likely to be defeated with reason or logic. Although a snow sphinx can speak, it generally greets its prey with claws and teeth rather than riddles or philosophical conversation.

Physically, this fearsome creature is well adapted to harsh habitats, such as ice-covered mountains or arctic plains. It has wide paws to stop it sinking into soft snow and thick fur to ward out the cold. The sphinx's muscular wings carry the same spotted markings as its fur; they are strong enough to withstand the bitter winds that whistle across the tundra.

entries.name: Great Fir Drake
entries: Guardians of flourishing alpine forests, great fir drakes live peacefully among their saplings. Each day, the iridescent drakes use powerful magic to replenish their forest's soil and promote the growth of their beloved fir trees. Over the centuries, villagers and townsfolk have learned to live in peace with these largely benevolent beings.

People who live near a great fir drake's lair can visit its forest home and leave the drake small shiny tokens under trees they wish to cut down. If the people return the next day to find the tokens have been gathered and taken, they know the great fir drake has given its blessing for those tree to be felled. In thanks, villagers decorate the trees with lights to resemble the drake. Those who fail to leave an offering for the drake's hoard and cut down its fir trees enrage the legendary creature, and should prepare to face its thrashing, needle-covered tail.

entries.name: Snowborn
entries: The snowborn are a young species, and have existed for less than fifty years. They first appeared during a notably long and cold winter, which snowborn commonly refer to as 'The First Flurry'. Beyond that, little is known about their creation, though elemental magic was clearly involved. New snowborn have appeared and vanished over the years since their origin, yet the pattern of their life and rebirth remains a mystery even to them. Each fleeting snowborn lives for up to 20 years.

A snowborn's body is formed of compacted snow. They have a small sphere for a head, branch-like limbs, and they can harden into ice to protect themselves. Despite their coal eyes and carrot noses, they perceive the world as keenly as any other species. Snowborn enjoy using clothing as self-expression, like a jaunty hat or colourful scarf.

entries.name: Tarandus
entries: For millennia, the tarandus have been known as a society of explorers devoted to charting and understanding the world. Their culture prizes discovery, and they believe that their lives are best spent travelling, observing and creating maps that guide others along safe paths.

All tarandus possess antlers that rise roughly a foot above their heads. Their dark-red noses can emit a gentle glow, often used for reading maps in dim light or signalling danger to their allies. Tarandus fur ranges from deep brown to pure white, shifting with age, climate or diet. They usually wear simple outfits, though more ornate garments and armour may be loaned to individuals by their herd in honour of taking on a specific role or responsibility.

Their settlements are filled with map-halls and navigation schools, where trained explorers record the land, stars and seas with care. Some tarandus dedicate their lives to perfecting the art of map making, while others roam the world as scouts, guides or couriers, ensuring that their knowledge of routes and geography remains current.

Tarandus herds are large and communal, sharing duties such as child-rearing and foraging. They maintain strong ties between herds through regular gatherings where new maps and discoveries are exchanged. As most tarandus are used to the safety and rhythm of herd life, those who travel alone often join adventuring groups as temporary companions.

entries.name: Hederan
entries: Hederans are living embodiments of alpine trees, sentient beings of bark and leaf whose bodies host moss, holly and fungi. Their outer skin is made of thick bark that toughens with age, and beneath lies a network of green, sap-filled muscle. Twigs and berries sprout unpredictably, with the brightest clusters gathered around their heads. Their leaves and bark vary in colour, and are as diverse as the lands they live in.

Hederans have extraordinary lifespans, with some reaching over a thousand years of age. Every two centuries or so, a hederan enters a rare blooming phase when the flowers on its body release pollen and a single silver seed forms upon its back. The seed must be planted within a week, or it will wither away, but from it a new hederan sapling will grow.

Once planted by their parent, a hederan forms a deep bond with the soil of its homeland. They serve as guardians of winter forests, and maintain the balance of nature. Solitary by nature, they can live for centuries without meeting another of their kind, and no one knows how many exist across the world.

entries.name: Canisar
entries: Canisars are proud, fox-like humanoids, renowned for their fierce sense of kinship. They are famously described by others as having wits as sharp as their teeth. Their thick fur hides powerful muscles, and each of their fingers ends in a retractable claw. Respect is hard to gain from a canisar, but they will defend their friends with tenacity and devotion.

Canisars are covered in coarse fur that can vary between deep brown, grey, white, orange or black, which often comes with facial stripes or ringed markings. Most canisars live in woodland burrows, hidden beneath thick vegetation, mud or snow. Others roam the surface world, integrating into wider society while maintaining ties to their original burrows. Canisar culture is deeply ancestral, guided by reverence for family and lineage. Each canisar travels with stories and relics of their ancestors, and gives gifts to their friends and family throughout the year during different canisar festivals.
